title: Zero and Negative Exponents
kid_friendly_explainer: An exponent tells us how many times to multiply a number by itself. But what happens when the exponent is zero or negative?
A zero exponent means the value becomes 1 — as long as the base isn't zero.
A negative exponent doesn't mean the number is negative. It means the base is on the wrong side of the fraction line, so we FLIP it!

core_rules.name: Zero Exponent Rule
core_rules.plain_english: Any nonzero number raised to the power of 0 equals 1.

core_rules.name: Negative Exponent Rule
core_rules.plain_english: A negative exponent means 'flip it' — move the base across the fraction line and make the exponent positive.

core_rules.name: Fraction with Negative Exponent
core_rules.plain_english: If a fraction has a negative exponent, flip the fraction before applying the exponent.

walkthrough: Step 1: A negative exponent means 'flip' the fraction: (3/2)^2.
Step 2: Now square both numerator and denominator: 3^2 / 2^2.

easy.directions: Use the zero and negative exponent rules to simplify each expression.

items.hint: Anything to the zero power equals 1.
Flip 5 over the fraction line.
Flip 2, then cube it.
Flip the fraction once.
Flip a and square it.

medium.directions: Simplify negative exponents in both numbers and variables.

items.hint: A negative exponent in the denominator moves the base up.
Only x has a negative exponent, so move x to the bottom.
Flip both a and b together.
Flip the fraction, then square it.
Multiply exponents by −1 and simplify.

challenge.directions: Use both zero and negative exponent rules together.

items.hint: x^0 = 1. Then simplify y^{-3}.
Apply exponent −2 to both 2 and x^{-2}.
Subtract exponents for each base.
Flip and apply exponent 2 to both parts.
Flip first, then square each factor.

extreme.directions: Combine multiple exponent rules — zero, negative, and power of a power. Simplify step by step.

items.hint: Remove y^0, flip, and multiply exponents.
Multiply all exponents by −2.
Simplify each group first, then divide.
Flip, then square numerator and denominator.
Simplify inner parentheses first, then the outer exponent.

teacher_notes: Explain that negative exponents are a 'flip signal' — they tell students to move the base across the fraction line.
Zero exponents are special — emphasize that only nonzero bases work with this rule.
Encourage kids to say 'flip and switch the sign of the exponent' aloud to remember the concept.
